Charleston,\bSo\fth\bCarolina\b29409\bUSA\b siripong.potis\fk@citadel.ed\f\b Abstr\bct.\bThis\bpaper\bdescribes\ban\balternative\bformalism\bfor\bThai\bsyntax\bparsing\bbased\bon\ba\b lexicalized\b tree\b adjoining\b grammar\b (LTAG).\b We\b first\b briefly\b present\b some\b formal\b backgro\fnd\b concerning\b LTAG,\b which\b is\b necessary\b for\b an\b \fnderstanding\b of\b LTAG\b and\b its\b application\bto\bThai.\b\bSpecifically,\bwe\baddress\bseveral\biss\fes\bregarding\bdiffic\flties\bin\bparsing\b Thai\b sentences\b and\b how\b to\b resolve\b these\b iss\fes\b \fsing\b LTAG.\b S\fch\b diffic\flties\b arise\b for\b several\breasons\bas\bfollows.\bFor\bone\bthing,\bThai\bsentences\bdo\bnot\bcontain\bdelimiters\bor\bblanks\b between\b words\b while\b Thai\b words\b lack\b inflectional\b and\b derivational\b affixes.\b Moreover,\b inconsistent\b ordering\b relations\b within\b and\b across\b phrasal\b categories\b characterize\b Thai\b sentences\b as\b well\b as\b the\b fact\b that\b they\b sometimes\b contain\b discontin\fo\fs\b sentence\b constit\fents\b in\b their\b constr\fction.\b Finally,\b we\b disc\fss\b f\ft\fre\b research\b on\b a\b novel\b almostparsing\b approach\b based\b on\b LTAG\b for\b handling\b compo\fnd\b m\flti-word\b extraction\b in\b a\ftomatic\bThai\bword\bsegmentation.\b\b Keywords: \fh\bi-L\fAG, \fh\bi synt\bx p\brsing\b

sections.title: 1 Introduction
paragraphs: Research\b on\b the\b syntactic\b analysis\b of\b Thai\b sentences\bby\b comp\fter\b has\b been\b carried\b o\ft\b for\b several\b decades.\b Thai\b grammars\b have\b been\b developed\b \ftilizing\b vario\fs\b grammar\b formalisms\b based\b on\b the\b two\b theories\b of\b syntax,\b namely\b dependency\b grammar\b and\b phrase-str\fct\fre\b (constit\fency)\bgrammar\bor\btheir\bcombination.\bVoras\fcha\b(1986)\bwas\bone\bof\bthe\bfirst\bresearchers\b to\b \fse\b Gazdar’s\b Generalized\b \thrase-Str\fct\fre\b Grammar\b (G\tSG)\b in\b his\b research.\b Immediate\b Dominance\b (ID)\b r\fles\b and\b Linear\b \trecedence\b (L\t)\b r\fles\b were\b \fsed.\b \tornprasertsakil\b et\b al.\b (1990)\blater\bemployed\badditional\bFeat\fre\bSpecification\bDefa\flt\b (FSD)\b constraints\b of\b G\tSG\b to\b describe\b three\b types\b of\b sentence\b str\fct\fres\b incl\fding\b verb\b and\b no\fn\b phrases.\b Aroonmanak\fn\b (1990)\b developed\b a\b nondeterministic\b parser\b called\b CU\tARSE\b based\b on\b a\b dependency\b representation\b of\b syntax.\b The\b parser\b \fses\b a\b chart\b as\b its\b central\b data\b str\fct\fre.\b As\b part\b of\b a\b project\bon\bmachine\btranslation\bof\bAsian\b lang\fages,\b Sornlertlamvanich\b and\b \thantachart\b (1992)\b \fsed\b a\b combination\b of\b phrase-str\fct\fre\b and\b dependency\b grammars.\b \thrase-str\fct\fre\b grammar\b r\fles\b were\b \fsed\b to\b identify\b locally\b well-formed\b phrase\b patterns,\b and\b th\fs\b red\fce\b lexical\b ambig\fities,\b based\b on\b the\b relatively\b fixed\b relation\b of\b the\b positions\b of\b Thai\b words\b and\b their\b syntactic\broles.\bThen,\bsyntactic\bdependency\bstr\fct\fres\bamong\bthe\bwords\bwere\bgenerated\bbased\b on\bverb\bs\fbcategorization\binformation.\bFinally,\bthe\bsyntactic\bdependency\bstr\fct\fre\bwas\bmapped\b to\b a\b semantic\b one\b by\b \ftilizing\b a\b lexical\b f\fnctional\b grammar.\b W\fwongse\b and\b \tornprasertsak\fl\b (1993)\bintrod\fced\ba\bprobabilistic\bapproach\b\fsing\ba\bleast\bexception\blogic\b(LEL)\bmodel\bof\bdefa\flt\b reasoning\bto\bresolve\bambig\fities.\b\totis\fk\band\bHarper\b(1996)\bproposed\ban\balternative\bformalism\b 444 23rd Pacific Asia Conference on Language, Information and Computation, pages 444–453 called\bConstraint\bDependency\bGrammar\b(CDG).\bCDG\bparsers\br\fle\bo\ft\b\fngrammatical\bsentences\b by\b propagating\b constraints\b developed\b based\b on\b a\b dependency-based\b representation\b of\b syntax.\b CDG\b is\b capable\b of\b efficiently\b analyzing\b free-order\b lang\fages\b beca\fse\b order\b between\b constit\fents\bis\bnot\ba\breq\firement\bof\bthe\bgrammatical\bformalism.\bSince\bThai\bexhibits\bsignificant\b word\b order\b variation,\b \fsing\b CFG\b to\b describe\b Thai\b is\b c\fmbersome\b beca\fse\b n\fmero\fs\b r\fles\b wo\fld\b be\b needed\b to\b cover\b all\b possible\b config\frations\b of\b a\b constit\fent.\b Secondly,\b The\b CDG\b approach\bprovides\ba\b\fniform\bmechanism\bof\bconstraint\bpropagation\bfor\beach\bknowledge\bso\frce,\b i.e.,\b lexical,\b syntactic,\b semantic,\b and\b pragmatic\b information,\b in\b resolving\b ambig\fities\b d\fring\b parsing.\b The\b constraints\b for\b each\b knowledge\b so\frce\b can\b be\b independently\b developed\b and\b applied.\b A\b CFG\b parser,\b on\b the\b other\b hand,\b does\b not\b provide\b a\b good\b coordinating\b scheme\b beca\fse\bit\bis\bincapable\bof\bselectively\binvoking\bdifferent\bknowledge\bso\frces.\b \b\b\b\b\bIn\b this\b paper,\b we\b propose\b an\b alternative\b formalism\b based\b on\b Lexicalized\b Tree\b Adjoining\b Grammar\b(LTAG)\bfor\bThai\bsyntax\bparsing.\bBefore\bdescribing\bo\fr\bimplementation\bof\bLTAG\bfor\b Thai,\b we\b present\b a\b brief\b introd\fction\b to\b Thai\b morphology\b and\b syntax\b in\b the\b next\b section\b and\b arg\fe\bwhy\bLTAG\bappears\bto\bbe\ban\battractive\bchoice\bfor\bThai\bgrammar\bdevelopment.\b

sections.title: 2 An Overview of St\bnd\brd \fh\bi
paragraphs: Standard\b Thai,\b the\b foc\fs\b of\b this\b research,\b is\b the\b official\b lang\fage\b of\b Thailand\b and\b \fsed\b in\b cond\fcting\b official\b b\fsiness\b and\b legal\b matters.\b It\b is\b also\b the\b medi\fm\b of\b instr\fction\b in\b government\bschools\bthro\fgho\ft\bthe\bco\fntry.\bSince\ba\bformal\bling\fistic\banalysis\bof\bstandard\bThai\b is\bnot\ba\bprimary\bgoal\bof\bthis\bresearch,\bthis\boverview\bis\bby\bno\bmeans\bintended\bas\ban\bexha\fstive\b ling\fistic\bdescription\bof\bstandard\bThai.\bIn\bthis\bsection,\bwe\bpresent\ban\boverview\bof\bstandard\bThai\b concerning\bits\bmorphology\band\bsyntax.\bWe\balso\bo\ftline\bseveral\biss\fes\bregarding\bdiffic\flties\bin\b parsing\bThai\bsentences.\bThe\boverview\bis\bgiven\bto\bprovide\ba\bling\fistic\bframework\bfor\bs\fbseq\fent\b description\bof\bThai\bgrammar\bdevelopment.\b

sections.title: 2.1 Morpho\togy
paragraphs: A\bcontin\fo\fs\bstream\bof\btext\bcan\bbe\bbroken\b\fp\bby\breaders\binto\bsmaller\band\bmeaningf\fl\bparts-\ba\b disco\frse\binto\bsentences,\bsentences\binto\bwords,\band\bwords\binto\bmorphemes.\bA\bmorpheme\bis\bthe\b smallest\bling\fistic\b\fnit\bwhich\bhas\ba\bmeaning\bor\bgrammatical\bf\fnction.\bLexical\bmorphemes\bhave\b meaning\b in\b and\b of\b themselves;\b grammatical\b morphemes\b specify\b the\b relationship\b between\b two\b lexical\bmorphemes.\bFree\bmorphemes\bcan\bstand\balone;\bbo\fnd\bmorphemes\bcannot.\b \b\b\b\b\bAltho\fgh\b Thai\b is\b commonly\b tho\fght\b to\b be\b a\b monosyllabic\b lang\fage\b like\b Chinese,\b many\b words\b are\b disyllabic\b and\b trisyllabic.\b Most\b disyllabic\b words\b are\b names\b of\b plants\b and\b animals.\b Others\bare\bKhmer-related.\bThe\bfollowing\bdescribes\bthe\bword\bformation\bprocess\bin\bThai.\b

sections.title: Affix\btion
paragraphs: The\bfirst\b process\b is\b the\b affixation.\b Affixes\b (i.e.,\bprefixes\b and\b s\fffixes)\b are\b bo\fnd\b grammatical\b morphemes\b which\b are\b attached\b to\b other\b lexical\b morphemes\b (i.e.,\b roots)\b to\b compose\b words.\b There\b are\b two\b types\b of\b affixes:\b inflectional\b and\b derivational\b affixes.\b Inflectional\b affixes\b are\b grammatical\bdevices\b \fsed\b to\b indicate\b syntactic\b or\b semantic\b relations\b between\b different\b words,\b i.e.,\b the\b concepts\b of\b pl\frality,\b possessive\b case,\b degree\b of\b comparison,\b or\b tense.\b Derivational\b affixes\bare\b\fsed\bto\bindicate\bsemantic\brelations\bwithin\ba\bword,\bb\ft\bnot\bsyntactic\brelations\bo\ftside\b the\bword.\bThey\balso\bindicate\ba\bchange\bin\bmeaning\bor\bsyntactic\bcategory\b(i.e.,\bpart\bof\bspeech)\bfor\b the\broots\bto\bwhich\bthey\bare\battached\b(e.g.,\b\fn-).\b \b\b\b\b\bWith\bthe\bexception\bof\bloanwords,\baffixes\bare\bnot\bpart\bof\bthe\bmorphological\bstr\fct\fre\bof\bThai.\b Neither\binflectional\bnor\bderivational\baffixes\bare\b\fsed\bto\bcompose\bwords.\bIn\bother\bwords,\bThai\bis\b considered\b an\b isolating\b or\b analytical\b lang\fage\b in\b which\b sentences\b are\b constr\fcted\b from\b seq\fences\bof\bfree\bmorphemes;\beach\bword\bconsists\bof\ba\bsingle\bmorpheme,\b\fsed\bby\bitself\bwith\bits\b meaning\b intact.\b Semantic\b and\b grammatical\b concepts\b are\b expressed\b thro\fgh\b the\b \fse\b of\b free\b morphemes\brather\bthan\bthe\b\fse\bof\ba\bchange\bof\bform\bor\baffix.\bFor\bexample,\b\fnlike\bEnglish\bwhich\b 445 indicates\b pl\frality\b thro\fgh\b a\b change\b of\b form\b (e.g.,\b I\b to\b We)\b or\b tense\b thro\fgh\b the\b \fse\b of\b affix\b (e.g.,\b-ed\bfor\bpast\btense),\bThai\b\fses\badditional\bwords.\b \b\b\b\b\bNevertheless,\bThai\bdoes\bmake\blimited\b\fse\bof\baffixation.\bMost\baffixes\bare\bof\bKhmer\bor\bIndic\b (\tali\b and\b Sanskrit)\b origin.\b This\b process\b acco\fnts\b for\b restricted\b types\b of\b nominalization,\b semantic\bextension,\bintensification,\band\bstylistic\b marking.\b Adjectival\b or\b stative\b nominalization\b are\bformed\bwith\bthe\bprefix\b‘khwaam-’;\baction-verb\bnominalizations\bare\bformed\bwith\bthe\bprefix\b ‘kaan-’\b (meaning\b activity).\b Some\b verbs\b admit\b either\b type\b of\b nominalization.\b Specialized\b nominalizations\bto\bform\bagent\bno\fns,\boften\bocc\fpational,\bare\bformed\bwith\bthe\bprefix\b‘nak-’.\bIn\b addition,\bKhmer-derived\bnasal\binfixes,\be.g.\b–am(n)-,\bare\ba\bcommon\bform\bof\bderivation.\b

sections.title: Compounding
paragraphs: Compo\fnding\b is\b a\b process\b which\b forms\b new\b words\b from\btwo\b or\b more\b independent\b words,\b a\b mere\bj\fxtaposition\bor\ba\bcollocation\bof\btwo\bor\bmore\bwords\bwith\bno\balteration\bin\bthe\bconsonants\b and/or\bvowels.\bThe\bcomponent\bwords\bof\bthe\bcompo\fnd\bcan\bbe\bfree\bmorphemes,\bwords\bderived\b from\baffixation,\bor\beven\bwords\bof\b the\b compo\fnd\b can\b be\b free\b morphemes,\b words\b derived\b from\b affixation,\bor\beven\bwords\bformed\bby\bcompo\fnding.\bCompo\fnding\bin\bThai,\breg\flarly\bof\bthe\btype\b head\b+\bmodifier,\bis\bwidespread\band\b\fs\fally\bserves\ba\bf\fnction\bsimilar\bto\baffixation.\bCompo\fnds\b can\b be\b disting\fished\b from\b syntactic\b phrases\b by\b differences\b in\b stress\b patterns.\b The\b stress\b placement\bis\bdetermined\bby\bthe\bmorphological\bderivation\bof\bthe\bcompo\fnds.\bFor\bexample,\bthe\b first\b syllable\b of\b a\b 2-syllable\b compo\fnd\b is\b always\b \fnstressed.\b For\b written\b lang\fage,\b this\b distinction\bis\bnonexistent.\b

sections.title: Redup\tic\btion
paragraphs: Red\fplication\b is\b process\b of\b forming\b new\b words\b either\bby\b do\fbling\b an\b entire\b free\b morpheme\b (total\b red\fplication)\b or\b part\b of\b it\b (partial\b red\fplication).\b Thai\b makes\b extensive\b \fse\b of\b red\fplication.\b Total\b red\fplication\b is\b possible\b for\b most\b adverbs\b of\b manner\b and\b for\b adjectivals,\b and\b is\b \fsed\b to\b intensify\b or\b express\b command.\b Collective\b pl\fralization\b of\b a\b restricted\b set\b of\b no\fns\bdenoting\bh\fmans\bis\bderived\bthro\fgh\btotal\bred\fplication.\bThe\bred\fplicative\bextension\bwith\b alternation\b of\b vowels\b and\b sometimes\b tones\b and\b consonants\b is\b a\b style-sensitive\b means\b of\b intensification\band\bsemantic\belaboration.\bAlso,\bcolloq\fial\bintensification\bof\badjectivals\binvolves\b red\fplication,\b with\b tone\b shifted\b to\b high\b on\b the\b first\b red\fplicated\b syllable.\b For\b action\b verbs,\b red\fplication\bmay\biconically\bencode\ba\bd\frative\bor\brepetitive\baspect\blike\bprogressive\bin\bEnglish.\b

sections.title: 2.2 Synt\bx
paragraphs: Syntax\b describes\b sentence\b str\fct\fre\b or\b the\b principles\b by\b which\b words\b are\b organized\b into\b a\b sentence\b in\b a\b lang\fage.\b Syntacticians\b classify\b Thai\b as\b having\b a\b s\fbject-verb-object\b (SVO)\b pattern\b as\b the\b most\b favored\b word\b order.\b Th\fs,\b Thai\b is\b commonly\b referred\b to\b as\b an\b SVO\b lang\fage.\b However,\b other\b common\b orders\b freq\fently\b appear,\b especially\b in\b colloq\fial\b or\b informal\b conversation.\b The\b following\b paragraphs\b address\b lexical\b categories\b and\b s\fbcategorization,\bas\bwell\bas\bbasic\bword\border.\b

sections.title: Lexic\b\t C\btegories \bnd Subc\btegoriz\btion
paragraphs: In\b any\b given\b lang\fage,\b a\b large\b n\fmber\b of\b words\b often\bexhibit\b the\b same\b properties,\b which\b s\fggests\b that\b they\b can\b be\b gro\fped\b together\b into\b classes\b called\b lexical\b categories.\b Word\b categorization\b is\b \fs\fally\b based\b on\b different\b criteria\b (or\b their\b combination):\b morphological,\b syntactic,\b or\b semantic\b properties.\b For\b example,\b according\b to\b Aroonmanak\fl\b (1990),\b lexical\b categorization\bof\bThai\bwords\bconsists\bof\bfive\bmajor\bcategories\bbased\bon\bsemantic\bproperties\bof\b words:\b No\fn(N),\b Verb(V),\b Determiner\b (DET),\b A\fxiliary\b (AUX),\b and\b Relator\b (REL).\b Each\b major\bcategory\bis\bf\frther\brefined\bor\bs\fbcategorized\b\fsing\bboth\bsyntactic\band\bsemantic\bcriteria.\b S\fbcategorization\b represents\b a\b finer\b distinction\b within\b each\b major\b category.\b A\b no\fn\b is\b s\fbcategorized\binto\bcardinal\bno\fn,\bproper\bno\fn,\bprono\fn,\bcommon\bno\fn,\band\bclassifier.\bA\bverb\b 446 is\b either\b an\b active,\b stative,\b existential,\b or\b eq\fative\b verb.\b Ther\b are\b left\b and\b right\b determiners\b depending\b on\b the\b position\b of\b the\b no\fn\b it\b modifies.\b S\fbcategories\b for\b a\fxiliaries\b incl\fde\b left\b modal,\bleft\birrealis,\bleft\baspect,\bleft\battrib\fte,\bright\battrib\fte,\band\bright\baspect\ba\fxiliary.\bA\brelator\b can\bbe\ba\bpreposition,\bcomplementizer,\bor\bconnector.\bIn\baddition\bto\bthese\bfive\bmajor\bcategories,\b there\b is\b a\b special\b class\b of\b words\b called\b particles.\b Their\b primary\b f\fnction\b is\b to\b end\b \ftterances.\b There\b are\b three\b gro\fps\b of\b particles.\b One\b gro\fp\b marks\b a\b statement\b and\b forms\b yes-no\b q\festion;\b the\bsecond\bshows\brespect\btoward\bthe\baddressee;\band\bthe\bthird\bindicates\ba\bspeaker’s\bmood.\b

sections.title: B\bsic Word Order
paragraphs: As\bmentioned\babove,\bthe\bsimplest\bsentence\bconstr\fction\bis\bs\fbject-verb-object.\bHowever,\bthere\b are\bother\bconstr\fctions,\bs\fch\bas\bsimple\bcomparative\bconstr\fction,\bcomplementation,\bembedding,\b topicalization,\byes/no\bq\festions,\band\bcontent\b(wh-)\bq\festions.\bInversion\bof\bword\border\bdoes\bnot\b occ\fr\b except\b in\b the\b case\b of\b topicalization.\b This\b topic-initial\b word\b order\b is\b object-s\fbject-verb\b (OSV),\bwhere\bO\bis\btopical\bor\bthematic.\bAnother\bcharacteristic\bfeat\fre\bof\bThai\bis\bthe\bobligatory\b \fse\b of\b classfier\b when\b q\fantifier\b is\b present\b with\b no\fn.\b The\b most\b \fs\fal\b order\b is\b no\fn+q\fantifier+classifier.\bThe\bhead\bno\fn\bdetermines\bthe\bchoice\bof\bclassfier.\bThis\bconstr\fction\b becomes\bdiscontin\fo\fs\bwhen\bnew\binformation\bq\fantifiers\bare\bpresent,\band\bthe\bno\fn\bis\bseparated\b from\b the\b q\fantifier\b and\b the\b classifier.\b A\b more\b controversial\b constr\fction\b is\b verb\b serialization\b where\b verbs\b occ\fr\b in\b series\b with\b or\b witho\ft\b and\b explicit\b intervening\b conj\fnction.\b Verb\b order\b may\brepresent\bthe\bprogress\bof\ba\bcomplex\bevent\bor\ba\bpassive\bconstr\fction\blike\bEnglish.\b

sections.title: 2.3 Difficu\tties in P\brsing \fh\bi Sentences
paragraphs: Despite\b increasing\b concerted\b efforts\b among\b Thai\b \fniversities\b and\b government\b agencies,\b a\b satisfactory\bapproach\bto\banalyzing\bThai\bsentences\bhas\bnot\bbeen\bobtained.\bDiffic\flties\bin\bparsing\b Thai\bsentences\barise\bfor\bseveral\breasons.\b \b\b\b\b\bFirst,\b written\b Thai\b sentences\b do\b not\b contain\b delimiters\b or\b blanks\b between\b words.\b Unlike\b English,\bThai\bwords\bare\bnot\bflanked\bby\ba\bblank\bspace.\bWords\bare\bconcatenated\bto\bform\ba\bphrase\b or\bsentence\bwitho\ft\bexplicit\bword\bdelimiters.\bThis\bcreates\ba\bproblem\bfor\bthe\bsyntactic\banalysis\b of\b Thai\b sentences\b beca\fse\b most\b parsers\b operate\b on\b words\b as\b the\b smallest\b syntactic\b \fnit\b in\b a\b sentence.\bTo\bovercome\bthis\bproblem,\ba\bword\bsegmentation\bmod\fle\bm\fst\bbe\badded\bto\bthe\bfront\b end\bof\bmost\bThai\bparsers.\bIt\bmay\bseem,\bon\bthe\bs\frface,\bthat\bthe\bproblem\bhas\bbeen\bsolved.\bB\ft,\bon\b the\bcontrary,\ba\bnew\bproblem\bhas\bbeen\bcreated.\bInstead\bof\banalyzing\ba\bsingle\bsentence,\ba\bparser\b m\fst\bnow\banalyze\bm\fltiple\bsentence\bhypotheses\bcomprising\ba\bcombination\bof\ball\bpossible\bwords\b generated\bby\bthe\bword\bsegmentation\bprocess.\bFor\b example,\b given\b the\b following\b string\b of\b Thai\b characters, ,\b two\b possible\b sentence\b hypotheses\b are\b generated\b given\b dictionary\b look\fp.\b\b a.
\b b.

paragraphs: In\b this\b section,\b we\b introd\fce\b a\b different\b approach\b to\bThai\b syntactic\b parsing\b based\b on\b a\b Lexicalized\b Tree\b Adjoining\b Grammar\b (LTAG).\b We\b will\b first\b briefly\b present\b some\b formal\b backgro\fnd\b concerning\b LTAG,\b which\b is\b necessary\b in\b \fnderstanding\b o\fr\b implementation\b for\b Thai\bas\bwell\bas\bthe\brest\bof\bthe\bpaper.\b  448

sections.title: 3.1 An Overview of L\fAG Form\b\tism
paragraphs: Lexicalized\b Tree\b Adjoining\b Grammar\b is\b a\b tree-rewriting\b grammar\b formalism\b \fnlike\b Context-Free\bGrammars\band\bHead\bGrammars\bwhich\bare\bstring-rewriting\bformalisms.\bLTAG\bis\bbased\bon\b Tree\b Adj\fnct\b Grammar\b (TAG)\b formalism\b originally\b proposed\b by\b Joshi,\b Levy,\b and\b Takahashi\b (1975)\band\blater\bextended\bto\bincl\fde\blexicalization\b(Schabes,\bet\bal.,\b1988)\band\b\fnification-based\b str\fct\fres\b(Vijay-Shanker\band\bJoshi,\b1991).\b \b\b\b\b\bThe\bprimitive\belements\bof\bthe\bLTAG\bformalism\bare\belementary\btrees.\bEach\belementary\btree\b is\b associated\b with\b at\b least\b one\b lexical\b item\b on\b its\b frontier\b since\b one\b of\b the\b important\b characteristics\bof\bLTAG\bis\bthat\bit\bis\blexicalized.\bThe\blexical\bitem\bassociated\bwith\ban\belementary\b tree\bis\bcalled\bthe\banchor\bof\bthe\btree.\bAn\belementary\btree\bserves\bas\ba\bcomplex\bdescription\bof\bthe\b anchor\b and\b provides\b a\b domain\b of\b locality\b over\b which\b the\b anchor\b can\b specify\b syntactic\b and\b semantic\b (predicate-arg\fment)\b constraints.\b That\b is,\b each\b lexical\b item\b is\b anchored\b to\b a\b tree\b str\fct\fre\bthat\bencodes\bs\fbcategorization\binformation.\bFor\bexample,\ba\btransitive\bverb\bis\banchored\b to\ba\btree\bthat\bincl\fdes\ba\bs\fbject\bN\t\band\ban\bobject\bN\t.\bElementary\btrees\bare\bof\btwo\btypes:\binitial\b trees\band\ba\fxiliary\btrees.\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b \b\b\b\b\bInitial\b trees\b are\b minimal\b ling\fistic\b str\fct\fres\b that\b contain\b no\b rec\frsion.\b They\b incl\fde\b trees\b containing\bthe\bphrasal\bstr\fct\fres\bof\bsimple\bsentences,\bN\ts,\betc.\bIn\binitial\btrees,\ball\binternal\bnodes\b are\blabeled\bby\bnon-terminals\band\ball\bleaf\bnodes\bare\blabeled\bby\bterminals\bor\bnon-terminal\bnodes\b marked\bfor\bs\fbstit\ftion.\bThe\bsymbol\b(↓)\bis\b\fsed\bto\bindicate\bthe\bs\fbstit\ftion\bsite.\b \b\b\b\b\bA\fxiliary\b trees\b are\b \fsed\b in\b representing\b rec\frsive\b str\fct\fres\b which\b are\b adj\fncts\b to\b basic\b str\fct\fres,\bs\fch\bas\badverbials,\badjectivals,\betc.\bAll\binternal\bnodes\bof\ban\ba\fxiliary\btree\bare\blabeled\b by\bnon-terminals\bwhereas\ball\bleaf\bnodes\bare\blabeled\bby\bterminals\bor\bnon-terminals\bnodes\bmarked\b for\b s\fbstit\ftion,\b except\b for\b one\b non-terminal\b node\b marked\b as\b foot\b node.\b The\b foot\b node\b is\b marked\bby\ba\bsymbol\b(*)\band\bm\fst\bhave\bthe\bsame\blabel\bas\bthe\broot\bnode\bof\bthe\btree.\b \b\b\b\b\bThe\b LTAG\b formalism\b defines\b two\b operations\b for\b combining\b elementary\b trees:\b s\fbstit\ftion\b and\b adj\fnction\b operations.\b The\b s\fbstit\ftion\b operation\b inserts\b an\b elementary\b tree\b into\b another\b elementary\btree\bat\bthe\bs\fbstit\ftion\bnode.\bThe\broot\blabel\bof\bthe\btree\bbeing\binserted\bm\fst\bmatch\bthe\b label\bat\bthe\bs\fbstit\ftion\bnode\bof\bthe\binserted\btree.\bIn\ban\badj\fnction\boperation,\ban\ba\fxiliary\btree\bis\b inserted\binto\ban\binitial\btree.\bThe\blabel\bof\bthe\broot\band\bfoot\bnode\bof\bthe\ba\fxiliary\btree\bm\fst\bmatch\b that\bof\bthe\bnode\bof\bthe\binitial\btree\bwhere\bthe\ba\fxiliary\btree\bis\bto\badjoin.\bThe\bres\flting\binitial\btree\b is\bsplit\bat\bthe\badjoined\bnode\bby\bthe\ba\fxiliary\btree.\b \b\b\b\b\bAnother\bcharacteristic\bof\bLTAG\bis\bthat\bit\bis\bfeat\fre-based.\bA\blexical\bor\bgrammatical\bfeat\fre\b str\fct\fre\b is\b associated\b with\b each\b node\b in\b a\b tree.\b This\b feat\fre\b str\fct\fre\b contains\b information\b abo\ft\b how\b the\b node\b interacts\b with\b other\b nodes\b in\b the\b tree.\b For\b example,\b by\b \fsing\b the\b case\b feat\fre,\b we\b can\b constrain\b a\b transitive\b verb\b to\b anchor\b to\b a\b tree\b that\b takes\b a\b s\fbject\b N\t\b with\b nominative\b case\b marker\b and\b an\b object\b N\t\b with\b acc\fsative\b case\b marker.\b Each\b node\b of\b an\b elementary\btree\bis\bassociated\bwith\btwo\bfeat\fre\bstr\fct\fres\b(FS),\bthe\btop\band\bbottom.\bThe\bbottom\b FS\b contains\b information\b relating\b to\b the\b s\fb-tree\b rooted\b at\b the\b node\b while\b the\b top\b FS\b contains\b information\b relating\b to\b the\b s\fper-tree\b at\b that\b node.\b Feat\fres\b may\b get\b their\b val\fes\b from\b three\b different\bso\frces:\b1)\bthe\bmorphological\binformation\bof\bthe\blexical\bitems\bthat\banchor\bthe\btree:\b2)\b the\bstr\fct\fre\bof\bthe\btree\bitself;\band\b3)\bthe\bderivation\bprocess\bof\b\fnifying\bfeat\fres\bfrom\btrees\bthat\b adjoin\b or\b s\fbstit\fte.\b \tarsing\b of\b a\b sentence\b is\b s\fccessf\fl\b only\b when\b both\b feat\fre\b str\fct\fres\b in\b each\bnode\bof\bthe\btree\b\fnify.\bThe\bres\flt\bof\bcombining\bthe\belementary\btrees\bis\bcalled\bthe\bderived\b tree.\b In\b addition,\b there\b is\b also\b a\b derivation\b tree\b which\b is\b the\b tree\b that\b records\b the\b history\b of\b composition\b of\b the\b elementary\b trees\b associated\b with\b the\b lexical\b items\b in\b the\b sentence.\b This\b derivation\btree\bcan\bbe\binterpreted\bas\ba\bdependency\btree\bwith\b\fnlabeled\b arcs\b between\b words\b of\b the\bsentence.\bThis\bimplies\bthat\belementary\btrees\bcombine\bboth\bphrase-str\fct\fre\binformation\band\b dependency\binformation\bin\ba\bsingle\brepresentation.\b  449

sections.title: 3.2 L\fAG Imp\tement\btion for \fh\bi
paragraphs: According\b to\b Joshi\b et\b al.\b (2002),\b large\b scale\b grammars\b have\b been\b constr\fcted\b by\b hand\b for\b English\bat\bUniversity\bof\b\tennsylvania,\bUSA\b(XTAG\bGro\fp\b2001)\band\bFrench\b(at\bthe\bTALANA\b gro\fp,\b University\b of\b \taris\b 7,\b France)\b and\b somewhat\b smaller\b ones\b for\b German\b (at\b DFKI,\b Saarbrücken,\bGermany),\bKorean\band\bChinese\b(at\bUniversity\bof\b\tennsylvania,\bUSA),\band\bHindi\b (at\bCDAC,\b\t\fne,\bIndia).\bTo\bthe\bbest\bof\bo\fr\bknowledge,\bLTAG\bhas\bnever\bbeen\bapplied\bto\bThai.\b O\fr\b decision\b to\b try\b to\b apply\b LTAG\b to\b Thai\b syntax\b parsing\b can\b be\b attrib\fted\b to\b several\b considerations.\b For\b one\b thing,\b the\b str\fct\fre\b of\b Thai\b (i.e.,\b its\b grammatical\b system)\b has\b been\b extensively\b st\fdied\b by\b Thai\b ling\fists,\b and\b there\b is\b eno\fgh\b evidence\b pointing\b to\b the\b fact\b that\b phrase-str\fct\fre\b grammar\b is\b well\b s\fited\b for\b describing\b Thai.\b Altho\fgh\b there\b are\b many\b formalism\bbased\bon\bphrase-str\fct\fre\btheory,\b s\fch\b as\b CFG,\b we\b opted\b for\b LTAG\b beca\fse\b of\b its\b generative\b capabilities\b and\b its\b key\b properties\b incl\fding\b lexicalization,\b extended\b domain\b of\b locality\band\bfactoring\bof\brec\frsion\bfrom\bDomain\bof\bDependency.\bThis\bis\bvery\bimportant\bfor\bThai\b beca\fse\bThai\bwords\black\binflectional\band\bderivation\baffixes\bas\bmentioned\babove.\b The\b position\b of\bthe\bword\bin\bthe\bsentence\balong\bwith\bits\blexical\bcategory\b(possibly\bits\bs\fbcategory)\bdetermines\b its\b syntactic\b f\fnction\b and\b how\b it\b is\b related\b to\b the\b rest\b of\b the\b sentence.\b This\b s\fggests\b that\b the\b formalism\bsho\fld\bbe\bable\bto\bcapt\fre\bdependency\binformation\bamong\bwords\bwithin\bthe\bsentence\b as\bwell.\bAnd,\bas\bmentioned\bat\bthe\bend\bof\bthe\bprevio\fs\bsection,\b elementary\b trees\b of\b LTAG\b can\b capt\fre\bboth\bphrase-str\fct\fre\band\bdependency\binformation\bat\bthe\bsame\btime.\b paragraphs: ( – \b compo\fnd\b verb\b meaning\bto\bdefy\b-\b\bpreposition\b‘to’)\b \b \b\b\b\b\bThe\b compo\fnding\b process\b has\b long\b been\b a\b problem\b in\b the\b design\b of\b many\b Thai\b word\b segmentation\b algorithms.\b This\b represents\b a\b classic\b compo\fnd\b m\flti-word\b extraction\b in\b Thai\b morphological\b analysis.\b This\b problem\b arises\b beca\fse\b Thai\b words\b are\b concatenated\b to\b form\b a\b phrase\bor\bsentence\bwitho\ft\bexplicit\bword\bdelimiters.\bMany\bresearchers\bviewed\bthis\bphenomenon\b as\b a\b word\b segmentation\b problem.\b However,\b we\b believe\b that\b the\b problem\b can\b be\b solved\b at\b a\b higher\blevel\bof\b analysis,\b namely\b the\b syntactic\b level.\b This\b is\b beca\fse\b the\b ambig\fities\b that\b arise\b from\b
